title.narrative: Enhance the capacity of Female Police in Yemen: Mainstreaming a gender-based approach within the law enforcement

description.narrative:
I. Introduction In November 2018, a contract (reference No. AVT16/BZ120646A) was signed between the state of Netherlands, represented by the Minister for Foreign Trade and Development, legally represented by the Ambassador of Yemen and Penal Reform International to implement a project titled “Enhance the capacity of Female Police in Yemen: Mainstreaming a gender-based approach within the law enforcement”. The project overall goal is to Enhance peace and security efforts in Yemen through building the capacity of the female police unit at the MOI. Through achieving the following outcomes. 1) Female police officers in the female police unit are better able to maintain law and order according to human rights standards and rules of administration of justice. 2) A gender sensitive approach in the work of MoI is mainstreamed through improved safeguards for female police officers. 3) Barriers to women reporting crimes are removed 4) Improved international standards and best practice in ensuring equal opportunities for women in the police force The target groups of this project are MOI, 700 female police officers that were hired by the governement in the South, and the Police Academy. While the final beneficiaries of the project are: society at large in Yemen, with a focus on vulnerable groups including women, children, marganlised groups, that will benefit from the presence of well trained women police officers. To achieve the overall goal and the specific results of the project, PRI worked closely with relevant governmental stakeholders including (MOI, female police unit affiliated to the family protection department at MOI); Kindly see Annex No. 1 “MoI- PRI MoU governing the project implementation”. PRI has a strong partnership with the MoI and our contact person for the project from MoI side is the Deputy Minister, colonel Ali Lakhshaa, who provided full support to the project work and activities. This working relation was governed by the project theory of change outlined below in Figure No.1. which illustrates the sequence of events, activities and interventions taken within the course of the project, and how they contribute to achieving the project goal. In March 2021, PRI requested a cost extension for the project which focused on consolidating the work achieved by the project in the initial phase and had contributed to overcome the delays that took place due to the war, COVID and the weather. The extension focused on supporting the establishment and sustainability of the female policy academy through delivering trainings to a new cohort of the female police officers , and advocate for their hiring within all police departments. The report will be divided into two sections, section I Project Problem Statements and Political Overview, and Section II Achievements of Project Results and Activities. Section I: Problem Statement and Political Overview: This section will include a brief account of the political situation in Yemen; it shows the degree to which those political conditions have affected the project implementation. Since the war started in 2015, the political and security situation in Yemen continued to be a major challenge for the criminal justice system. The ongoing instability in Aden and the southern governorates, and the clashes led by different groups including Al-Qaeda, and the Southern separation council against the official government caused a challenge and slowed down the implementation of the project activities, but despite that the MoI continued to express their full political support for the project and its objective and their determination to deploy female police to serve in several locations with the aim of facilitating justice delivery and enhancing the access of females to the police as part of their international commitments and image.
A closer scene of the political situation in Yemen, showed a very volatile and unpredictable situation due to the active armed conflict and clashes between the internationally recognized government (IRG) and the transitional council (TC). The clashes started in March 2020 and continued till the month of Ramadan. In addition to natural disasters that encountered the country, heavy rains, and flooding which started in mid-April 2020 continued across the country. Flooding has damaged roads, bridges, and the electricity grid, and contaminated water supplies, cutting access to basic services for thousands of people. In Sana’a, flooding caused widespread disruption to services as the city was overwhelmed by floodwaters. In Aden, power cuts have continued since the floods in April, causing a heightened risk of diseases such as malaria and cholera.
Similar to other countries around the world, Yemen has been suffering from the impact of COVID-19, yet with a magnified effect or impact, due to the effect of the war on the Yemeni health system, as years of war has shattered the country's health system, leaving it incapable of coping with a pandemic. Many of Yemen's medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning. Clinics are reported to be crowded, and basic medicines and equipment were lacking - in a country of 27.5 million people there are only few hundred ventilator machines. COVID-19 had also an impact on slowing down the work, where the work on renovating the police academy had to stop due to the pandemic and the lockdown forced by the authorities, training workshops had to be suspended till the lockdown is left.
During the extension period of the project-(March 2021-March 2022), continuous conflicts and clashes between the international recognized government (IRG) and the transitional council (TC) lead to the transfer of some Ministers from Aden to Sauon to work form there, as the case of the minister of interior, which affected the services delivered by the ministry in Aden, such as the delay of the official decree announcing the female police academy as a branch for the Police academy, and the suspension of the monthly salaries of employees of the Ministry of Interior, including female police officers, and not being able to allocate a budget for the female police academy as part of the annual police budget. All these circumstances affected the ability of the female police officers to be deployed as required after their participation in the training delivered throughout the extension phase.
Challenges faced by Female police in Yemen: Based on PRI’s Interviews with the female police officers enrolled in PRI capacity building interventions during the first year of the project, the female officers have expressed that they have experienced previous to the project many setbacks because of the lack of training due to lack of resources allocated to them, and as Yemen is a conservative society, they didn’t give much attention, or chances to the fact that women police needed continuous training, in addition to the need to expand their opportunities through enrolment and through on the job practical training, and theoretical knowledge which would help them increase their ranks to be leaders in the police forces . The need for the police academy to be built and maintained was a high expectation needed to compensate for the lack of experience and knowledge that the women police force faced. Some Officers felt left out and felt that they were not given the equal right of men to perform their tasks, and duties, yet they remained excited, and eager to earn knowledge, and gain experience to perform at their highest capabilities in order to serve their country, and their cause of equality. The trainings organized by PRI as part of this project provided them with a good head start, but the continues need for extra knowledge and training skills is still an obstacle due to the lack of resources.
Theory of change The project theory of change was affected by the political challenges, natural disasters and the impact of COVID-19, and some changes needed to be introduced at the outcomes level to response to that. The original plan was that the project targets all of the 700 police officers, however, due to the delays in finalizing the academy that was impacted by the ongoing conflict and the division at the government level in Aden, the floods, and the COVID-19, not all the 700 officers were able to benefit from the training, only 400 officers, were the final beneficiaries. However, due to the difficult financial situation that the government in Aden was facing, more financial support will be needed till the academy is able to function smoothly and based on annual plan. The logic behind the initial theory of change is still valid and follow the logic and the project approach that was chosen when the project started. It worth to mention that the project team have a process of continuous revision of the theory of change and the risks on the ground and acted on adopting mitigating factors that aimed at reducing these risks to achieve the results of the project and its outcomes. However, the political situation and all the delays were beyond PRI control. However, the project non-cost extension has helped PRI in reaching out for its initial target in terms of reaching out to female officers. In total 857 female police officers were targeted by the project and benefited from the different training programs that PRI delivered through the academy.

IV. Updated Risk Assessment Risk Likelihood Impact High/medium Negative Management COVID-19 Pandemic: Unpredictable Negative PRI Management have communicated the impact of COVID-19 and Natural disasters encountered during the reporting period on the progress of the proposed activities under this project with the Dutch counterparts and discussed the possibility of the need of no-cost extension and the slight shift in minimal activities as communicated by PRI regional Directorate, yet PRI was able to deliver the required activities with slight shifting in time. Political instability in Yemen High/ medium On the political level, there was no progress in implementing the Riyadh Agreement. In July 2020, President Abd Rabbo Mansour Hadi assigned Dr. Moein Abdel-Malek to form a new government, but until the date of this report, the government was not formed. As for the governorate of Aden, a new governor was appointed at the end of July 2020. Which led to the delay in the implementation of some activities such as the building of the female police administration and the implementation of 6 friendly units. regular risk assessment done by MENA regional office in consultation with the project team based in Yemen and with MOI. PRI tolerated low-medium range of risks inherent in field work, and in districts where high risk is associated with field work, relevant activities were moved to safe areas, as a way to mitigate the risk, and make sure that the project goal and objectives are not jeopardized by temporary developments on the ground. Regional offices have the experience and expertise in many geographic areas in the MENA region, Asia, Africa, central Europe, to determine when work is safe to be carried out and will adapt their work accordingly to achieve the sought-for results. Additionally, PRI worked through local staff who are well trained and neutral, and not targeted, with a low risk to their safety and security. In relation to regional and international experts, PRI used all safety procedures followed by the UN, including staying in safe hotels and avoiding high risk areas; additionally, the MOI is willing to provide security and guards for the experts if needed. PRI stayed on continuous communication with the related stakeholders represented mainly by the MoI, to be updated on the progress and the exchange information on the project activities.
Access to professional development for women police officers
Medium / low A barrier to the career advancement of women in policing may take the form of inequitable access to training courses, and eventually to promotion in their career. A male dominated work may affect the equal opportunities offered to women. In addition police employees, including women, living in remote and rural communities have less opportunities, especially if the course involves an extended residential component. Women with both family and career responsibilities may be less inclined to apply for training. PRI’s project objective is to provide the right for women to join the police forces and receive adequate training for a range of different work responsibilities. PRI worked on deploying the women in different field areas. However, as part of the sustainability of the project goal and objectives, through regular meetings with the senior officials of the MoI. PRI built a curricula that require involving the women police in the future training and academic course. The training by PRI will empower women to become a significant number and an asset in the police units. PRI will also provide best practices related to equal training opportunities for women in distant areas from the centre.
Lack of social support Medium The lack of social support can be another barrier for women to succeed in their duties in the field. A police woman required to intervene at the different levels of the justice sector might face the strain and the effects of environmental or external barriers. women trained might not sustain their jobs, PRI previous experiences in the justice sector in Yemen, including at high managerial level, showed a high social support for women equal participation. Historically Yemen, was leading in women participation as judges, and even as police officers. Prior to the conflict two thousand women officers were part of the police units, the armed conflict and the humanitarian situation forced them to leave (only sixty stayed). The project will build on previous successes, and social support to re-introduce the female element to police, empowered by professional training. PRI conducted advocacy campaigns with senior opinion leaders in the society, and will build the capacity of the media outlets to gain support of the different components of the society, including a follow up by media to the efficient interventions of women police in fields of women justice, and children in conflict with the law..

Project final beneficiaries: The final beneficiaries of the project are: society at large in Yemen, with a focus on vulnerable groups including women, children, marginalized groups. Direct beneficiaries: are MOI, 700 female police officers that were hired in the South, the Police Academy.

Section II. Achievements of Project Results and Activities: Despite the very volatile and unpredictable situation in Yemen due to the war between the Coalition led by Saudi Arabia and the Houthi, the political tension, and clashes between the international recognized government (IRG) and the Southern Transitional Council (STC) seeking the separation of the south of Yemen, leading to the suspension of the Ministry of Interior work in 2020. Adding to that the floods that flashed Yemen and contributed to the deterioration of the humanitarian crisis that are affecting millions of people, and the COVID- 19 Pandemic that resulted in shutting down the country and international travel and added severe pressures on the authorities and the daily life of people. Despite all of that Penal Reform International (PRI) managed successfully to implement project activities as originally planned with minor changes to the theory of change, a request for budget reallocation and none-cost extension of two months.
II.I Overall Goal During this project, the first cornerstone was put in place to increase women role in building peace and security in Yemen. 400 female officers that are fully trained and equipped with knowledge and skills about law enforcement duty, human rights standards in applying justice and maintaining order are now deployed in several locations within police force to serve the Yemeni population. A female police unit is assigned the task of managing these officers, located at MOI in an allocated building that is fully furnished and equipped with needed tools, is established, with ca lear structure, tasks and responsibilities and identified qualifications and detailed TORs for each post they recruit and deploy on the ground with a proper monitoring and follow up system for their performance. A Female Police Training Academy that aims at providing both foundational and specialized training for female officers to join the police force is established, and ready to accommodate 100 police officers per training that can last for 6 months and include comprehensive filed and theoretical training on policing, use of force, investigation of crimes, border control, traffic, prison management, human rights standards …etc. This foundational work that invested in shaping and establishing the main institutions that will handle the work and management of female police officers, is a first step in empowering women within law enforcement authorities and give them the opportunity to play an equal role to their male peers. Noting that access to such equal opportunities was hindered as outlined by the project theory of change by lack of capacity due to lack of training and education, difficult working environment in the field and socio-cultural barriers within both MoI and the society. The project targeted and contributed successfully to change and overcome those barriers by providing the needed training and capacity building for 857 officers, creating six pilot locations that change the working environment for women in the field to enable them to fulfill their tasks and remove the physical barriers in the criminal investigation department in Aden. The pilot locations are at Tawahi port, at Rabat check point, at Al-Alam check point, at Aden airport, and at Taiz center prison for the benefit of 165 female officers who also started working on shift nights. In addition, to working towards changing the culture inside the ministry of Interior by drafting and adopting a gender mainstream policy at the top level of the MoI. The project theory was based on the fact, that if female officers receive the proper training and required capacity building, they will be able to work effectively in the field and better serve society and access to justice, especially for women who will be more encouraged to report a crime to a female officer because they feel more comfortable and safer. The rationale of the project was that the reinvolvement of women to work and serve at the police would have an impact on building peace and security in Yemen by increasing people’s trust in police services and encouraging women to seek justice. It was noted that in 2018 when PRI started its work, the number of active female officers who are on duty within the MOI in both Sanaa and Aden did not exceed 100 in total. 20% of them were only in Aden, and Few of them were able to reach high ranks within the MOI; only 3 or 4 reached the rank of general. However, today, more than 2500 female officers are hired in the South and around 3200 female police officers in North and South.
This increase in the number is one of the main outputs under objective one of the National Action plans of women peace and security (Res 1325), output No. 10, “Increased the representation of women in the Army and Security Forces,” would not have been possible without the project work and support provided to the MOI.
This quantitative increase not only impacted increasing the number of female officers; it also had a qualitative effect on the services provided for women who come in contact with the law. The project captured the impact of involving female officers within the police force on people feeling safer, their satisfaction with services provided by female officers, and women’s willingness to report crimes, as the figures below show. In 2013, only 5.48% of women said that they are willing to report a crime alone, while in 2019, and due to the presence of female officers at police stations, the percentage went up to 14%. While 94% of the public reported feeling safer inside police stations having a female officer around. This proves that the project theory of change and rationale was accurate.
Goal indictor NO.1: Percentage of the public reporting “feeling safer” since the introduction of the female police unit According to the interviewed sample of the public, 94% of the public reported feeling safer inside the police station having female officers around, yet only 6% did not witness any change.
Goal indictor NO.2: Percentage of the public who “are satisfied” with the work of the female police unit and its contribution towards peace and security efforts. How do you rate your satisfaction with the service provided by the women police on a Three-Likert scale. According to the interviewed sample of the public, the survey results showed that (59%) of the sample were strongly satisfied, (29%) were moderately satisfied, whilst only (12%) of the sample are not satisfied.
Respondents Profile Respondents Disaggregated by Sex Male 16.67% Female 83.33%
Respondents Disaggregated by Age Group 18-29 10% 30-49 70% Above 50 20%
II.II Project outcomes: The project four main outcomes were all achieved through the project lifetime: Outcome No.1: Female police officers in the female police unit are better able to maintain law and order according to human rights standards and rules of administration of justice. 857 officers (initial target 700) received comprehensive training on maintaining law and human rights standards and they have now the skills needed to reflect this knowledge on their daily work and in service. However, PRI believes that more follow-up and mentoring is needed for these female officers to accompany them while dealing with challenges and help them and enhance their skills in other selected topics and areas after they have been deployed to the filed. The academy was established, and training inside its premises started and it will be the main pillar of project sustainability since its impact will remain after the project ends. Number of female police officers who feel confident and able maintaining law and order in a variety of settings.
To what extent do you feel confident and able maintaining law and order in a variety of settings 77.5 % Extremely Confident 17.5 % Confident to a certain Extent 5.0 % Barely Confident 100 % Grand Total
Summary: 95% interviewed female police officers feel confident and able to maintain law and order in a variety of settings as a result of project activities, while only 5% attributed a low level of confidence  The 95% of female police officers which attributed a level of confidence relate that to the following reasons:  Women trainees had increased skills in several cases that already used and needed on duty  Having such trainings had increased the willingness of women to be deployed in various settings.  Several trainees had already been transferred into roles where they can use their new skills  Their colleagues (men) had increased confidence in the skills of their women counterparts and to work with them in various settings.
 While the other 5% who attributed a low level of confidence believe that they need to be enrolled into more series of trainings to be equipped enough to operate into all field different settings. Number of female police officers able to apply human rights standards and rules of administration and justice
According to the interviewed sample from the female police officers that benefited from the project capacity building interventions, the results show that the majority of the sampled are able to apply human rights standards within their work, either inside police stations, cross borders, or prisons. The sample was representative, and covered all duty stations, to ensure that all the female police officers to verify that they are able to demonstrate their capacity in applying human rights standards regardless of their duty station.
Extension Phase: The work of the extension phase has focused on expanding the achievements under the outcomes of the original project: Pillar No. 1: Continue supporting the training at the police academy with the aim of reaching out to a larger number of female police officers and test the validity of the develop curriculums in the field and reflect any changes needed. Training workshops have continued to be delivered at the police academy targeting additional female police officers, who received 5-days specialized trainings covering the curriculums developed. Output 1. 600 female police will be fully trained using the training program developed within the female police academy. 457 female officers received 5-days trainings titled "Developing women's police skills within law enforcement agencies on dealing with women's and children's issues". The trainees were mainly trained on topics related to basics of criminal investigations, criminal intelligence foundation, special operations, foundational drug control, gender-based violence, human rights principles, crime scenes, community policing, security media, foundation principles for prisons management and treatment of inmates according to international human rights principles.
As a results of the training workshops, the trainees increased their knowledge in the topics trained on, as during the training course, an assessment of the trainees’ capabilities was conducted to assess the change on the level of knowledge and skills reported by female officers. The results show an average learning gain equal to (+53) %, the following formula was used to compute the learning gain value: Learning Gain Formula= (Post test Score-Pre-Test Score)/ (Maximum Score-Pre-test Score). A detailed analysis of each course is summarized in the table below: # Training Date/Location Training Venue Total number of Trainees Trainees Demographics Trainees Average Age Assessment Results-(Learning Gain) 1 3rd - 8th July 2021 Aden 60 (50% from Aden, 25% from Ibb, 25% from Lahej) 33 54% 2 3rd - 8th July 2021 Taiz 50 36 47% 3 10th -15th July 2021 Aden 60 (50% from Aden, 25% from Ibb, 25% from lahej) 34 49% 4 10th -15th July 2021 Hadramout 60 35 50% 5 7th -12th August 2021 Aden 60 (50% from Aden, 25% from Ibb, 25% from lahej) 34 56% 6 14th -19th August 2021 Aden 60 (50% from Aden, 25% from Ibb, 25% from Lahej) 36 53% 7 21st-26th August 2021 Aden 57 All the participants from Aden 33 58% 8 30th October - 4th November 2021 Aden 50 All the participants from Aden 31.6 58% 9 13 – 18 November 2021 Aden 50 All the participants from Aden 32 60% 10 21st – 25th November 2021 Aden 39 All the participants from Aden 32 61%
